abstract: Federal investigators are facing logistical hurdles as they seek to arrest two former JPMorgan Chase employees. | William A. Ackman’s tenacity has underpinned both his successes and failures. | Special purpose acquisition companies are thriving despite a record of failure. | A contest to buy the maker of Steinway & Sons pianos is ending in a diminuendo.
snippet: Federal investigators are facing logistical hurdles as they seek to arrest two former JPMorgan Chase employees. | William A. Ackman’s tenacity has underpinned both his successes and failures. | Special purpose acquisition companies are thriving de...
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators are facing logistical hurdles as they seek to arrest and criminally charge two former JPMorgan Chase employees at the center of the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss in London last year, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook.

abstract: At a news conference announcing the arrest of two former traders at JPMorgan Chase, the authorities also criticized the bank’s oversight of the London office where they worked.
snippet: At a news conference announcing the arrest of two former traders at JPMorgan Chase, the authorities also criticized the bank’s oversight of the London office where they worked.
lead_paragraph: More than three thousand miles from the Park Avenue headquarters of JPMorgan Chase, traders in an office building nestled near the Thames River disguised the extent of their losses as a huge bet spun out of control last year, federal authorities say.

headline.main: Charges Against 2 Traders Fault JPMorgan for Lack of Oversight
headline.print_headline: Charges Against 2 Traders Fault JPMorgan for Lack of Oversight

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

abstract: The Justice Department has learned an important lesson about putting on cases involving complex Wall Street financial machinations and has lined up a witness who can help explain its case to a jury.
snippet: The Justice Department has learned an important lesson about putting on cases involving complex Wall Street financial machinations and has lined up a witness who can help explain its case to a jury.
lead_paragraph: The so-called London Whale, whose trading in credit default swaps ended up costing JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion in losses, appears to have a new role as the linchpin of the government’s criminal case against two employees of the bank. His cooperation shows that the Justice Department has learned an important lesson about putting on cases involving complex Wall Street financial machinations that are said to have involved fraud.

headline.main: U.S. Puts a Helpful Face on Its Fraud Case

abstract: There is enough material to conclude that JPMorgan employees embarked on a foolhardy quest to trade their way out of trouble, and left the bank with $6 billion of losses.
snippet: There is enough material to conclude that JPMorgan employees embarked on a foolhardy quest to trade their way out of trouble, and left the bank with $6 billion of losses.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, bets worth hundreds of billions of dollars are valued using a considerable amount of guesswork.

headline.main: Unreliable Guesswork in Valuing Murky Trades
headline.print_headline: Unreliable Guesswork In Valuing Murky Trades
